text:
Using the <include> sub-element within the implicit FileSet of the 'jar'-task
doesn't work. The same filter expression within the 'includes'-attribute works
as expected.
creator: joachim.simon@web.de
bodewig@apache.org
text: Can you give us an example snippet?  Seems to work for me.

Example which works fine:
    <jar jarfile="${dist}/lib/jstov.jar">
      ... some other filesets ...
      <fileset dir="${lib}" includes="xsd/**/*.xsd xsd/**/*.xml xsd/**/*.xsl"/>
    </jar>

Example which doesn't work:
    <jar jarfile="${dist}/lib/jstov.jar">
      ... some other filesets ...
      <fileset dir="${lib}">
         <include name="xsd/**/*.xsd xsd/**/*.xml xsd/**/*.xsl"/>
      </fileset>
    </jar>

My original description was wrong, as I used an explicit fileset. Sorry for that.
creator: joachim.simon@web.de

text:
OK, I almost guessed it 8-)

includes="" accepts a space or comma separated list of patterns, <include name=""/>
expects a single pattern.  Your usage of <include> simply doesn't match anything.
Use multiple <include> elements.
creator: bodewig@apache.org
